columns.text: In this exercise, we are asked to determine the six-month risk free rate in Great Britain, Japan, and Switzerland.

**Exchange rate** is the value of a country's currency when expressed in *another country's currency*.  A **forward trade** is an agreement to *exchange currency in the future*. The *exchange rate in the agreement* of a forward trade is called a **forward exchange rate**.

We will look at Figure 21.1 of this book to answer the questions in the exercise.

The six-month forward rate of the following countries as shown in Figure 21.1 are as follows:

<center>


|Country |Six-month forward rate per US$ | 
|--|:--:| 
|Great Britain | £ 0.5929| 
|Japan | ¥ 102.21 | 
|Switzerland |SF 0.8779 | 

 
The current six-month risk-free rate in the United States is 1.3%

Next, the **spot rate** is the exchange rate in a spot trade. The **spot trade** is an agreement to exchange currencies based on the exchange rate on that date and must be settled within two business days.

The spot rate of the following countries as shown in Figure 21.1 are as follows:

<center>


|Country |Spot rate per US$ | 
|--|:--:| 
|Great Britain |£ 0.5920 | 
|Japan | ¥ 102.32 | 
|Switzerland |SF 0.8793 |

This formula gives us the **interest rate parity**.  It is the condition stating the difference of the interest rate of two countries is equal to the percentage difference between the forward exchange rate and the spot exchange rate.

Since what we need is the **six-month risk-free rate**, we will derived the formula of the interest rate parity. Hence, we will use the formula below:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{$R_{FC}$} &= \left(\dfrac{\text{$F_{180}$}-\text{$S_{0}$}}{\text{$S_{0}$}}\right)+\text{$R_{US}$}\\[10pt]
\end{aligned}$$

Where: 

$F_{180}$ =  forward exchange rate for six months (180 days) 

$R_{US}$ = Nominal risk-free rate of U.S. 

$R_{FC}$ = Nominal risk-free rate of a foreign country 

$S_{0}$ = Spot Exchange Rate
As a conclusion, the six-month risk free rate in Great Britain, Japan, and Switzerland are **1.45%, 1.19%, and 1.14%** respectively.
In this exercise, we need to determine the six-month risk-free rate in Great Britain, Japan, and Switzerland.

**Interest rate parity** is a concept that links the foreign exchange rate and interest rates in the country and states that if currencies are in equilibrium, the opportunity to make money by exchanging money alone cannot be used. 

The basic concept is that returns on investments in different currencies should be independent of interest rates in the country. Therefore, there will be no possibility of arbitrage in the foreign exchange markets - investors cannot claim profit by the difference between interest rates using foreign exchange as a means or method of investment.

**Interest rate parity** condition, for $t$ periods is:

$$\dfrac{F_t}{S_0}=(1+R_{FC})(1+R_{US})$$

where variables stand for:

$F_t$ - forward exchange rate for settlement at time t

$S_0$ - the spot exchange rate

$R_{US}$ - nominal risk-free interest rate for the US

$R_{FC}$ - nominal risk-free interest rate for a foreign country

To determine the six-month risk-free rate we will rearrange the interest rate parity condition. The formula we will use is: 
$$R_{FC}=\dfrac{F_t-S_0}{S_0}+R_{US}$$

Now, for every country, we will read values from the table in the $\textbf{per US\$}$ column (the amount of foreign currency that you can buy with $\$1$).

Let's substitute them into the formula obtained in the previous step. We know that the current six-month risk-free rate in the United States is $1.3\%$ and therefore, $t=6$.


For **Great Britain**:

$$\begin{aligned}

R_{FC} &=\dfrac{F_6-S_0}{S_0}+0.013&&\text{}\\
&=\dfrac{\pounds 0.7670-\pounds 0.7649}{\pounds 0.7649}+0.013\\
&=0.0157\\
&=1.57\%
\end{aligned}$$

The six-month risk-free rate in Great Britain is $\textbf{1.57\%}$.

For **Japan**:

$$\begin{aligned}

R_{FC} &=\dfrac{F_6-S_0}{S_0}+0.013&&\text{}\\
&=\dfrac{\yen 109.31-\yen 109.28}{\yen 109.28}+0.013\\
&=0.0132\\
&=1.32\%
\end{aligned}$$

The six-month risk-free rate in Japan is $\textbf{1.32\%}$.

For **Switzerland**:

$$\begin{aligned}

R_{FC} &=\dfrac{F_6-S_0}{S_0}+0.013&&\text{}\\
&=\dfrac{\text{CHF}\;0.9599 -\text{CHF}\;0.9712}{\text{CHF}\;0.9712}+0.013\\
&=0.00136\\
&=0.136\%
\end{aligned}$$

The six-month risk-free rate in Japan is $\textbf{0.136\%}$.
